div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, SATURDAY, APRIL 8, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: "Homocea" "Touches The Spot"
div.p: In all cases of cuts, burns, bruises, chafes, sores, ulcers, open Wounds, and cimilar ills of the flesh, anoint with Homocea on linen or lint.
Homocea for bruises, bites stings, swellings, sore throat, face-ache etc., gently rob and cover with Homocea on linen
Homocea is antiseptic, soothing, and healing,
Homocea allays inaflamtive, initature &c.
Homocea is the most wonderful relief and cure for piles known.
Homocea Embrocation is for rubbing of in pains of all kinds, rheumatic pains, strains, stiff joints neuralgia, etc.
Hippacea does in the kennel, stable, and farm, for all animals what Homocea does in the Household.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Slightly warmer weather has prevailed since Saturday but on the whole it has been pleasant.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: Enormous Damgage done
div.p: Vestcrnay moiniiy, a severe earthquake t.Mik litul «lso m ii northerly tliivou ■ ; ...ii Simla. Enormous damage v n. in-, :i . i u ns leased there has boon h . u.),: i .11 in.’, i:»piHally nt Lahore where , iay mu.allies eolnipscil. TheTawous mosques; Bombay, April 5. N ino Europeans and a considerable num-.. a ol natives weio Killou at Lahore. It is ibaied Uiat some Europeans were killed at the Alinsoouo Hut Station, to the South of Simla, v iu.ro not a blunting escaped the catastrophe, h is reported that every house at Dharmsala has noon Jeveiieit and that sotne-Europeans and in ■ iy natives Jiavo lit on kniotl. Delia suffered 'usiderauiy,-but none were killed, brum many iiei places tneie are no reports, owing to the interruption of the telegraphs.

div.head: family Jar
div.p: The daughter of Sheikh el-Sadai, whose matrimonial escapade created such exoiteuieut last summer, .has ieit her lather s troupe together with several members ot Ills lamtiy and household, and will probably stay some time with Princess Nazn lianem. Murderers Sentenced.—The Assize Court ol A siuul has eoudemue.i to death one Ahoui liussali4 iiamuda, who murdered Sueikn Mu-dapiia Abd ei Ghani near Aleliawi station, iiamuda’s associate, Aialirous Mustapbu, has been sentenced to hard labour for life. Stray anu Ownerless Dogs found in the Baida Zeynab quarter of ' Cairo during the night ut Friday aud morning, ol Baturday, aud in the Boulao distrsct 'during the night ol Saturday and the morning ot Bunday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 16 vessels passed through the Cabal oil the 3rd inst., of which 7 were British, 1 Austrian, 1 German, 3 French, 2 Norwegian, 1 Dutch, 1 Egyptian. The day’s receipts were lrs. 377,732,Ui, making the total from the 1st inst. lrs. 1,157,362.50. Alexandria's (Jars.—There are almost two thousand oabn m Alexandria, and the annual inspeetiou is being earned out' by the police this week, it is not expected that more than two to three bundled cabs will, be con- demned as unsatisfactory. The general stand- ard ut tne cabs in Alexandria has greatly improved within the last tew years, "Poisson d’Avril."—The identity has not yet beon discovered of the practical joker, who succeeded in twice summoning Superintendent Lynn and the Alexandria Fife Brigade' to1 ( h i Ion’s establishment ou a false alarm of fire on All Fools’ Day. The person in question made uno of a telopliono in a pastry cook’s shop fur iho purpose. If discovered, it is possible t!uT civil proceedings will be instituted by the Alexandria Municipality against him. The Lottery Law comes into-force on Mon- d ty noxi, the 10th inst. It is stated that tho prohibition of the sale ol lottery tickets in the streets is the reason for the great and conti- nuous rise in the Credit Foncier Lottery ’bonds. Che issue ot the Italian Benevolent Society’s lottery tickets at Cairo has been suspended un.til a license has been obtained from the Government.

div.head: Alexandria Assizes
div.p: The Assize Court sittings will begin ou-April 12. There is a very big list of eases awaiting trial. Tbe trial of tho native butcher and shoemaker, who recently murdered an old woman under circumstances of great brutality, and disposed of the corpse in the Mahmoudieh Canal, will not be held until May 1. The two Greek ray alii, whose coining establishment was. lately raided at Karnious, will also be tried at the May Assizes. An Incident of a curious character is stated to have.'Occurred at the Geueral Assembly, according to “Al Mokattam.” Iti the proefes verbal'ot the first fitting of the Assembly mention was made of the Financial Advisor as being among those present. Ac the next meet- ing Sheikh Aly Youssef brought forward a motion that the above-mentioned statement in the proces-verbal should be withdrawn as being unconstitutional. 'Hie Slfoitcli’s-motion, however, was unanimously rejected and he thereupon asked leave to retire. Egyptian State.Raiiavays. —The Board of Administration informs us that the trains -“de luxe ’ ruuniug between Cairo aud Luxor will be suppressed from Cairo on and from Monday, loth inst, aud from Luxor on aud from Tues- day, 11th. The last "luxe’’ traiu will leave Cairo on Saturday, 6th, and Luxor ou Sunday, ‘Jib inst. Commencing from same date, dining and sleeping ears will be attached to the night trains leaving Cairo at 8 p.m. aud Luxor at 5.30 p.m., three times a week, as follows :— From Cairo, every Monday, Wednesday,' and Saturday ; from Luxor, ovory Tuesday, Thurs- day, aud Sunday.

Jes-‘ person, Miss L. and Miss G. Kirby, Mr. L. von Kuorring, Mr. aud Mrs. Kirkwood, Capt.- Kennedy, Mile Kuuiuier, Mrs. Park Lyll, Miss Park Lyll, Mme Lieberman, Gapt. and Mrs. W. Lcetbam, Mr. and Mme H. Landau, Mile Laudau, Mrs. and Miss Logan,.Mr. Mantikian, Mrs. Robert Mather, Miss MacArthur, Mr. and Miss Monk Bmith. Mr.- Louis Meillaz, Miss Ochs, Miss Perry, Air. W. div.head: Local theatre fire
div.p: The Abbas Ilelrny Theatre at Alexandria was destroyed by fire at an early hour this morning. Yesterday evoning, the usual performance was given by Gatti’s circus troupe,which ended at a quarter past midnight. At 12.20 a.m. the dynamo which supplies the electric light for tho theatre was stupped, and by 12.40 a.m. everyone connected with the theatre had left the building, nothing untoward having hap- pened. At half-past one in the morning, however, the alarm was Jgiven to the Fire Brigade that the “Abbas” was on fire, and on arriving on the spot a few minutes afterwards they found the large building in flames. The fire, which had apparently originated under the stage, had Spread with 'alarming rapidity to the auditorium and boxes, and in a short time the theatre resembled one vast roaring luruace. 'Fortunately, no one was in the building at the time; aud there was. no loss of life. 'The horses belonging to the circus troupe were, however, stabled under the stage and efforts were at once directed to saving the, animals. This was done, though three of the horses unfortunately were charred by the flames before they could be got out. v Little or none of the belongings of the unfortunate artistes belonging to the circus troupe cou.d be saved, as the conflagration had got a strong hold of the building. The efforts of the Fire Brigade were mainly directed to saving the walls of the theatre and the sur- rounding buildings, and it reflects great credit ou them that the lire was so successfufly kept wiihiu hounds, none of the adjacent buildings being affected. Bhortly after the outbreak the toot of the building collapsed with a tremen- dous crash, aud now nothing remains of the theatre but ‘the four walls, the whole place being entirely gutted. By 5 o’clock tms morning the fire was thoroughly mastered by tne Brigade, but the hremeh are still engaged in pumping water ou the smouldering mass ol charred wood- work and distorted iron pillars. The cause of the outbreak has not as yet been ascertained, and the sympathies of all .will be with the proprietors, Aiessjs. A.G. Moulerrato, when it is known that their loss is lyot covered by insurance. Thp theatre was built in 1834 aud was valued at something like £16,0011.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST
div.p: Of the £200,000 capital asked for the flota- tion of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Ltd., subscriptions to the extent of £300,000 have already come in up to mid-day to-day. Of this total, Egypt has subscribed £80,000 and England £220,000. The allotment of shares will, it is hoped,be completed by Sunday night.

div.head: crime
div.p: The Procnreur General thus oonolndes his review of crime:— That the inorease in orime, properly so called,' is less by half in 1904 than in; 1903, while criminal robbery has not risen (it has in fact fallen by 20)—that the rise in dMits is small in comparison with that of tbe last years, and no more than what might be fairly expected ; that such increase as there is accounted for by petty oases of assault and by a more -exacting standard in the Matter of false accusations while theft and crop-destroying have decreased, and cattle-poisoning not in- creased ; all this, while it oannot be oalled a brilliant result, at least indicates a less marked tendency of serious orime to remain on the increase, and is, so far, a matter for satisfaction.

div.head: MEHKEMEHS
div.p: The state of things, at present, is far from encouraging, and it is not astonishing that native reformers should be at length awaken- ing to the urgent necessity of serious re- forms in these Courts. Notably, in suits concerning private Wakfs, scarcely a week passes without some more or less serious com- plaint being received at this Ministry. The majority ol these private Wakf suits are pure questions of property and private rights and do not in any way affeot the religion of the people. Some of the more enlightened among native reformers therefore consider that the wisest and most satisfactory solution for all concerned would be for the Mehkamehs to hand overfall that relates to private Wakfs (Wakfs Ahly) to the Native Tribunals, retain- ing their competence in charitable Wakfs only (Wakts Khairy) which, being, of a more spiritual nature, fall mbre properly within the jurisdiction of religious Courts. This would certainly be a solution of the difficulty and itt> leasibihty is under the consideration of the Government. r

There has been some attempt, in quarters hostile to the project* _ to make capital out of the case of Mr. 'Beck and the stinHulus which that deplorable affair has given in England to a revival ol the agitation for a Court of Criminal Appeal. It may therefore perhaps be desirable to say a lew words on this subject. The suggestion is, of course, that the Egyp- tian'Goverument is proposing to abolish tlyi very safeguard which that case has shown to‘be imperatively necessary. Two considerations suffice to demonstrate -the fallacy iff this con- tention. The .first is that there is no real analogy between the functions of the Egyptian Court of Criminal Appeal—which it is proposed to suppress -here^—and those of the English Court ot Criminal Appeal—which it is desired to introduce at home. The one reviews, on the papers, jthe findings of (act of Tribunals which have heard the witnesses; the other would eitheT rehear the case de novo, witnesses and all, or else order anew trial at which the witnesses would be reheard. Whatever ad- vantages, therelore, might attach to the latter sj8tem—>they are highly problematical, the question being, as is generally admitted, an exceedingly controversial one—they are clearly not poMeased by the Egyptian institution which only exceptionally hears the witnesses. The secoud consideration is that the learned Commissioners appointed to iuquire into the Beck case, and report thereon to-the Home Becretary, have not, as a matter of fact, seeu fit to recommend the institution of a Court of Criminal Appeal, which they apparently regard —aud, it is submitted, rightly (1)—as calculat- ed to impair the dignity aud finality of the stti unices of the existing Criminal Courts. They content themselves with reoommending that some machinery should be provided for secur* ing the possible oousidcration, by a superior Court, of crucial poiuts of law decided by the judge at the trial. Such machinery already exists, in the Egyptian system, in the powers of the Court of Cassation, before which any oonvicted person has the faculty of showiug that a point of law bas beeu erroneously decided, to his disadvantage, and that he has consequently not had a fair trial, or that his oonviction is bad in law. If he suoceeds, the Court of Cassation either quashes the conviction or orders a new trial. We may, therefore, dismiss the idea that, the Beck case has any real bearing on the question of Assize Courts for Egypt. The qnes tiou remains yrhether, in any other respect, the situation has undergone any change since last year. Unfortunately it would appear that, it there has been any change, it has been tor the worse, crime having again increased, as may be seen from the report of the Procnreur General, though not, I am glad to say, in the same ratio as in the preceding year.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CIVIL CODE
div.p: After citing various oases to prove the defective drafting o * the Egyptian Civil Code, the Judioial Advisei remarks :— But it is not only in the drafting that Egyp- tian legislation is defective but also in the total omission of a number of important subjects and the locume and obscurities in the provisions regarding others. Thus Egyptian legislation contains no law of copyright, no law ef patents, no )»w of trade mark* and Egypt has conssqueitly been unable to adhere to the various International Conventions relat- ing to these most important subjects. There are constant compla inta from the commercial communities as to he loss and inoonvenienoe caused to them by tbe absence of a satisfactory law on these questions of every-day applica- tion. Again, the lan i law is very defective. The law of easements {servitudes) is so brief and incomplete as to givi i rise to constant difficulties. Wakfs aqd contracts of a similar nature are governed exolusivsly by Mohamedan law, which varies according to the different rite* not to mention the divergences in the views of the various authorities of the same rite. Obviously the only remedy for a body of legis- lation so radically defeotive is to simplify the modus legiferendi in Egypt. That the Egyptian Government should be oompelled to apply to fourteen Powers whenever it is desired- to efieot an improvement in Codes of the oalibre above described or to provide legislation cm subjects of the importance above referred to is obviously absurd

div.head: LAND REGISTRATION
div.p: In regard to the provisions of the above project, the Judicial Adviser remarks: “It would undoubtedly effect a very considerable change in the existing system and there can be very little doubt that the change would prove beneficial to the community at large. Indeed the defects of the present system are almost universally recognised and its continued existence is mainly due to the circumstance that it has hitherto proved impossible to formulate an acceptable’ scheme ’ to take its place. Now, howeve^ that such a scheme Jras been voted by a majority of the technical delegates, it is greatly to be hoped that political considerations may not induce the Powers to vhto the projeot and deprive Egypt of the benefits of a reform for whioh she has been struggling for so many years.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Yesterday the troopship “Dilwara” left Southampton with artillery and infantry drafts and various details on board for Gibraltar and Malta. Amongst the officers is Major C. L. E. Eustace-Robertson, D.S.O., King’s Royal Rifle Corps, who joins the 1st Battalion at Cairo. The “Dilwara” is due at Malta on the 2nd April and at Southampton on the 11th follow- ing. Her return will dose the trooping season of 1904-03. Captain Claude 3. Hawker, Coldstream Guard* commanding the Camel Corps of the Egyptian Army, has just been promoted to field rank in the Guards. Major Hawker entered the Guards close on fifteen years ago, the last six of which hare been spent in the Khedivefa service. He earned' tile Egyptian medal with clasps for the operations against tbe Khalifa in 1899, shortly after he joined the Egyptian Army. .A Captain S. J. Somerville, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, attached lately to the Indian Army, has been restored to the establishment of the inniskillings vice Captain R. C. Piero* appoint- ed adjutant of the 8rd Battalion. A feeling has been created that the War Office is trying to conceal the names of the fraudulent contractors in connection with the Cape Stores scandal. On the other hand, Mr. Arnold-Forster has given all the knowledge he possessed on the matter. There is every reason to believe that every difficulty was put in the way of his doing so. The battleship "London” (Captain Philip F. Tillard), which was commissioned at Ports- mouth on the 7th Juu* 1902, for service with the Mediterranean Fleet; will return home from that station on 24th prox. She will pay off the following day at Portsmouth, and will be recommissioned for another tour of service in Mediterranean waters. Her crew will be partially drawn from the battleship “Ramillies” in the Chatham-Sheerness Reserve.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: La salle da Zinnia dtait exceptionnellement garnie hier soir pour entendre los Coquelin d»n» lee deux comddies do Molidro, "Lo Malade Imaginaire” et “Le Mddeoin malgrd Ini”. Dans la preraidre M. Jean Coquelin jouait le rfile d’Argan, le malade par auto-suggestion, qu’il a fort bien interprets. M. Coquelin Cadet a dtd un Diafoirus iddal de bdtise; Mme Bouchetal a dtd trds bien dana son r6le de servante aviade, Milo Maufroy dojeunefille spirituelle autant que bien nde, Mile Damaury de marAtre hypo- crite et intdressde.

Dans "le Mddeoin malgrd lui” M. Coquelin Cadet jouait le rdle do Sganarolle qu'iljntor- prdte k la Comddie Fran^aise. II n’est pas besoin de dire si l'interprdtation a dtd bonne; do .commencement k la fin l’hilaritd a dtd gdndrale. M. Jean Coquelin a dtd naif A souhait en bonhomme Lucas, Mme Bouchetal trds bien, comme dTiabitude, dans son rdle de Martine et Mile Damaury dans celui de Jacqueline. Co soir la Cie Coquelin Cadet fait ses adieux aveo "Cadet Roussel," oomddie en trois aote3 de J. Richepin.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: II y a eu co matin une grande animation snr les prinoipales valours, la Banque Nationals, 1'Agricole, la Delta Light et la Daira. Le chiffre d'affaires a dtd surtout dnorme en Agricole.

La Banque National© a ddbutd k 27 5/16, at- taint 3713/16 pour retomber encldtnre k 37 5/8. L’Agrioole a ddbutd k 13, attaint 13 13/16 -pour fiuir a 13 9/16. Li Delta Light a tbuchd le prix da 14 7/8 k un moment donnd, mais en cldtnre le cours a tldchi k 14 5/8. De 36 5/16 la Daira ahaussd jasqu’k 37, pour clOturer k 26 5/8.

Le Crddit Foncier a attaint 329 achetenrs. D’autres valeurs sont dgalement en hausse, mais plus Idgdre: Ainsi l'Oasis remonte k 1 3/16. los Estates k 13/8, la Salt & Soda k 41/3, l’Anglo-American Nile A 5 13/16 et la Ramleh Railway k 8 3/16. L’ensemble du marchd est excellent aveo trds bonne tendance.

Siege Social, 106 Rue Royals Bruxelles. Le Conseil d’Administration a l’honneur de porter k la connaissance do Messieurs les Ac- tionnairee que l’Assemblde Gdndrale Ordinaire aura lieu k Bruxelles le Merorodi 3 Mai 1905, A 3 heurea de l’aprds-midi,Rue du Marais.55.

Commissaire au Cairo.— Pour Ctre admis k l’assemblde, Messieurs les Aotionnaires auront k bo con former k l’articlo 32 dee struts. Les actions doivent Ctre ddpo- sdes k Bruxelles, k la Banque BaLser & Co. En Egypte, dans l’un dee dtablissemente financiers oi-aprda nommds: Banque Impdriale Otto mane, Bank of Egypt, Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd., National Bank of Egypt, Crddit Lyonnais,Banque d’Athdnes et Cassa di Soonto e di Risparmio.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Assemblde Gdndrale annuelle de l'Alex- andria General Produce Association do 29 Mars 1905, a ddcidd d’apporter au Rdglement des oontrats de coton, los modifications sui- vantes: Page 18 — Remplacer l'aotuel art. 6, comme suit: Art 6 — La base des opdrations en Contrats est le "fully good fair brown". Les provenances de la Haute-Egypte et du Fayoum ne pourront Ctre livrdes qu’avec la diffdrence que le Comitd A- rduni au Comitd des Courtiers en Marohandises, fixera au cours des trois derniors jours, non-fdrids, de chaquo mois, pour le mois suivant En outre, pour avoir cette facultd, le vendeur devra fairo une bonification suppldmentaire fixe de P.T. 7 1/2 par Cantor do 100 Rotolis. Tout Contrat fait pour qualites autres que "fully good fair brown" est dgalement souinis au prdsentRCglement. Los affaires frauoo station sont aussi sou- misos au prdsent Rdglement Lo prix des Contrats est fixd par Cantor de 100 Rotolis poids net Page 19 — Remplacer los aOtuels art 7 et 7 Bis, comme suit: Art 7. — La bonification mutuelle est ap- pliqudo, sauf stipulations spdciales sur les Lettres Contrats, k tous les Contrats do "fully good fair brown" et de "fully good fair" Haute- Kgypto et Fayoum. La bonification mutuelle comprend un olas- sornont au-dessous et an classement au-dessus. Remplacer le second paragraphe de l’art 8, commo suit: Art 8.— Second paragraphe. Ils ont toutefois la faoultd de liner depuis "goodfair" jusqu'k "good’ moyennant bonifi- cation mutuelle (du vendeur k l’aohoteur ou vico-vorsa) des diffdrences do prix entre cos olassements et lej "fully good fair" fixdes pour le mois de'livraison par le Comitd A- rduni au Comitd des Courtiers en Marohandises. Page 28 — Remplaoer le premier paragraphe de Part 40, oomme suit -. Art 40.— Premier paragraphe. Le vendeur est tenu de remplaoer dans les 72 heures (les jours fdrida exolus) par une se- conds elder nitre liyraison de Coton reoevable, tout Coton rejetd par les experts, comme n’d- tant pas livrable.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration de la National Bank of Egypt a l’jionneur de porter k la con- naissauce des intdressds quo PAssemblde Gdnd rale Ordinaire des Aotionnaires rdnnie le Lnndi 20 Mars, 1905, an Sidge Social,' an Cairo, a fixd k 14 shelliDgs lo montant du dividende k payer par action pour Pqxeroioe olos le 81 Ddcembro 1904.— Ce dividende est payable centre remise du ooupon No. 5 k partir du 23 Mars 1905, an Silge Social de la Baoqne, au Caire, k sa Suo- oursale k Alexandrie, dans ses Agencesdos Provinoes et k son Agenoe de Londres 4 & 5, Jting William Street. 25628-8*-2

div.head: ALEXANDRIA BONED WAREHOUSE
div.p: The Coupon No. 6 is payable at the rate of £2.8.0 per share of £20, at tho offices of the Credit Lyonnais, from tho 3rd April 1905.

div.head: Mesopotamia
div.p: The Tigris enters its delta at Baled, near thesite of the ancient Opis, where were situated the famous weirs of antiquity and which were 'described by Tavernier. I used to think that these weirs were altogether artificial, bnt an examination of the site has made me think that they were natural bars of .vory hard conglomerate, as hard as. the compactest crys- talline limestone, which overlay stiff clay. The crests of the weirs wore probably artifi- cially raised. This conglomerate can bo seen to-day.along the left bank of the river from Samarra to nearly opposite Boled. It has a thickness of over ip metres at Samarra, and under it can be seen some 6 metres of stiff ~*any above the water’s edge of the Tigris. The conglomerate dips under the allurvum of the Tigris below Beled and its termination was in Probability a great cataract near Beled known .ally as "Sadd Nimrud,” or Nimrod’s dam. 'file Nahrwan and Dijail canals look out from above these weire^ .The Nahrwan canal was ruined by the Tigris changing its course, and the undermining and sweeping away of these great cataracts sealed the ruin of all the irrigation systems fed by the Tigris. From Beled to Bagdad the Tigris has a length of about 110 kilometres, and a width of from 4 kilometres to 350 'metres. Where the river is wide, it flows over a bed of shingle and has a velocity pf some 6 to 7 kilometres per hour. Navigation by sailing boats is impossible against the current.

From Bagdad to Gurnn,whore tho Tigris and Euphrates meet, the river has a length of 740 kilometres. The distance from Gnrna to Basra is 60 kilometres, and 100 kilometres further on is the Persian Gulf. Tho distances along the Tigris are therefore as follows . . ' From Beled to tho Sea J 1010 kilometres From Bagdad to Basra 800 „ From Bagdad to the Sea 900 „ After.leaving the rapids at Beled, the bed of tftj Tigris, like that of the Euphrates, is'every- where mud. The watere are yellow like those of the Tiber and the Euphrates. Bagdad is the real northern terminus of river navigation on the Tigris. It has taken, the place of the ancient Opis, which was further north

div.head: Letter to editor
div.p: A QUEER GRAMMAR. To rta Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—In reply to “Grammarian’s” lette.r in yesterday’s “Gazette,” I hive to inform him:— .(1) Not long before reviewing Dirr’s Arabic Grammar, the “Gazette” published my opinion of another grammar of the classical language, which was most flattering and which was afterwards shared by the editor of a well-known literary Arabic periodical inJJairo in his review of it (2) ’ Before sending in mf artiole on Dirr’s grammar I gave the book to a native friend (who is a competent Arabio scholar) to read and return to me with his opinion. He brought it after a few days and told me what he thought of it in fewer but severer words than I used. I then gave him my article to read and he approved of every word I said. Moreover, I have not yet met one who knew the book and did not share my opinion of it (3) Since sending my article to the "Ga- zette” 1 have learned that the book had been sent to an Euglish gentleman who is a well- known Arabic scholar, but although he refused to review it he marked here and there what he considered flagrant errors. The reason of his refusal is therefore not far to seek. . (4) I confirm every word I said in my review, but I cannot enter into any discussion with one who makes the ridioulous statement that it is grammatically correct to say el ingi- lyz tayiba because he means the English as a nation, and pretends that most of the other mistakes are obvious slips. (5) "Grammariau” has the fault of more than one other resident in the country who no sooner- picks up? a few words of Arabio (and before he could write a sentence correctly without the aid of some one else) than be rushes.to the press with a wonderful grammar of his own. It would have been better for “Grammarian” to study the language for many more years before venturing to write a book dealing with it (6) "Grammarian’’ will have to get all the , mistakes I pointed out, and many more, cor- ; need before the book ceases to be called a . "queer’’ grammar.. As regards his personal reference to me, there is no need for me to reply, as this sort of controversial method is beneath oontempt.— Yours very truly, The Whiter of the Review.

div.head: SUDAN EXPLORATION SHARES
div.p: Mr. Justice Kekewich in the Chancery Divi- sion on,Tahsday w§ek continued the hearing of the notion in whioh'Dr. Robert William Eelkin Rued the Palmerston Industrial and Finance Corporation, Ltd., and Mr. Alfred -Bridge, a company promoter, of-15, Cockspur-street, W., claiming rescission of an agreement to take 800 shares in the Sudan Exploration, Ltd., and a declaration that defendants were liable to indemnify the plaintiff in respect of all expen- ses incurred by him in relation to the transac- tion, or in the alternative damages for alleged misrepresentation. The corporation denied that its policy or business was controlled by Bridge, and did not admit that the representations alleged to have been made by him were made on behalf of the corporation or with its know- ledge. The.defendant Bridge pleaded that if he did. make any representations or statements concerning the present or future value of the shares they were bona fide expressions of opi- nion. Defendant Bridge counter-claimed againit the plaintiff for alleged misrepresentation.— Mr. P. Ogden Lawrence, K. C. and Mr. J; H. Simmons appeared for plaintiff, Mr. Ashton Cross for the Palmerston Corporation, and Mr. W. J. L Ambrose for Mr. Bridge. Plaintiff, continuing his evidence, said that up to the issue of the writ in this action he had never received a certificate for or transfer of the 800 shares in the . Sudan Exploration, Ltd.

In cross-examination by Mr. Ashton Cross, for the Palmerston Corporation, plaintiff said he knew the property whioh the Siidan Explo- ration had been formed to acquire. From his knowledge of the country witness believed the company's property to be valuable. Ho wa3 anxious to g|t some Sudan sbures if he could pay cash for them. The 10$. nominal shares could not be obtained for less than £1. Ho Btill believed in tho success of the Sudan Company if it was well managed. Mr. Ashton Cross said he agreed that the Palmerston Corporation sold the shares to Dr. Felkip and those shares had been delivered. Plaintiff, >n auswer to counsel, said ho be- lieved that the 800 shares were in the Sudan Company's hands' for transfer. In cross-examination by ' Mr. Ambrose, plaintiff said he understood that the Palmerston Corporation was to put the shares on the mar- ket at-£2 when the pooling-arrangement came to an end. He always understood that Bridge was actiug for the Palmerston Corporation. This concluded plaintiff's case, and Mr. Ashton Cross, submitting that ho case had been made out against the corporation, called Mr. Allred Bridge, who described himself as a director of. the Palmerston Corporation, of which,he said,tho plaintiff also beoamo a direc- tor. When the question of the Sudan Explora- tion shares was uuder discussion, plaintiff said that if he went into the matter ho should want a share of the profits, and witness then told him he had better become a director. Plaintiff, said witness, worked hand-in-hand with him in the Sudan matter, and advised the corporation to take up the shares. Witness denied that he ever made any representations to induce plaintiff to go into the share transaction, and he said that Dr. Felkin must have understood the whole transaction.

Cross-examined by Mr. Lawrence, witness said that he was a company promoter, and prior to his going to Cockspur-street he carried on business at 8, Union-court, FC., where he promoted a number of companies. May I take it that, all the companies you promoted oome to grief?—No.—Witness men- tioned the Pan-African Syndicate, Ltd., and the London and Provincial Dairy Company as suocossful promotions. Witness denied that at the time he left'Union-courtoxocutions were out against him at his office and at his house at Surbiton. Wore there any baukruptcy petitions present- ed against you ?—Yes. May I tako it that altogether 8, Union-court, got too hot for yon at tho time you migrated to the West End ?—No, not at all.—Witness said he sometimes advertised for directors willing to invest It was not true to suggest that witness was the Palmerston Corporation. He agreed that there was no entry in the mi- nute-books concerning the agreement with tho plaintiff. At the date of the signing of the bill by the plaintiff witness admitted that the only transfer of Sudan shares to the Palmer ston Corporation was one for 600 shqres. They had, however,’ made arrangements to acquirejurther shares.

div.head: Sports and Play
div.p: The abovo teams met at Abbassieh xm Wednesday last. Both teams hold a good record. The K.R.R’s, it seems, have not been defeated sinoe 1902, whereas the representatives of the Shamrook have only been beaten onoe in some sixtyodd matches,60 a good game was expected. The pitch was in splendid order as the Irishmen took the field in the following order : Goal, Dadgeon ; backs, Shanks and Reid ; halves, Millar, Nixon, and Smyth ; forwards, Todd, Hutton, Cunningham, Fallon, and Walsh. The Rifles won the spin of the coin and defended the city goals. There would be almost 900 spectators present when Cunningham commenced operations.. The opening minutes proved sensational as the Inuiskillings bom- barded the Rifles’ goal for fully five minutes. The custodian clearing the Rifles now broke away per Bibbleton, but Smyth robbed and returned. Todd getting possession centred well bnt Fallon sent behind. On the kick-off tho Rifles took play towards Dudgeon, but the latler was not to be oanght napping and cleared in Gillispie’s best style. At this stage the referee (a sergeant of the K.KR.’s) had occasion to retire owing to a misunderstanding of the roles, Mr. MoKenzie, Royal Engineers, filling the vacanoy (amid cheers). On play being resumed Cunningham got away and sent across to Todd, who outwitted two opponents and seut strongly into goal, where Fallon headed over the bar. Flay remained in midfield, until Fallon broke away, but when in a good position ho was! fouled by Bibbleton. A fight ensued, both players being oantioned. The Rifles’ right wiug now got away but Smyth intercepted and returned. Some very spirited play ’took place around the Rifles’ goal. At last, however, the custodian cleared. The Irishmen were now ’ having the best of matters and a shot of Cunningham's deserved a better fate. A free against the Green and Buff Brigade proved unproductive. It was close on half-timo as Hutton gave the Dark Greens’ defence some trouble. Half-time now arrived with the repre- seratives of the Shamrock pressing for all they were worth,but there was no score yet on either side.

After the usual refreshments both teams took tho field. The first thing noticeable was a great sprint by Todd. The ball, however, found touch. The Rifles now took play in hand, but Smith robbed the right wing -time after time. A corner to the Rifles looked ridrie too rosy for the Green and Buff Brigade, HoWeker Nixon cleared and the InniskUliugs were seen fio advantage. Walsh, however, ran the ball ovet tho liue. On the kick off Bibbleton got away, on his own, but Smith was on his track aneb blocked his passage once more. Not to be deniod, the Rifles got down towards Dudgeon and scored, but Johnny Bibbleton was given offside. On resuming, Millar got away on his own, and alter dodging a couple of opponents sent across to Cunningham, who had a good try for goal. The Rifles now pulled themselves togother and worked their way down towards Dudgeon but Nixon and Smith were not to be beaten so easily and play was once more trans- ferred, when Hutton got well away and gave to Todd, who aont in a "daisy cutter” to tho Custodian, who fell on the ball but too late, as Fallou gut the ball at his toe and into the net it went, drawing first blood for the Innis- killings amidst deafening cheers. Oa the ball being centred the K.RR’s got away but’ Reid returned the ball. Great was the excitement that now prevailed (at this stage Mion was injured and had to retire). Both teams were now playing a most determined and very hard game. If anything, the Inniskillingswere having tho best of matters at this stage. The shield holders were playing a fine combination game. It was a treat to watoh the five forwards play so woll considering tho circumstances under which they were placod. It was now wearing np to full'time as Walsh missed the much desired spot by inches. Shortlyafterthereferee’s whistle sounded for full time, leaving the Inniskillings winners of one of the most exciting games that ever took place in Cairo, and still undefeated. Final result 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers*-! Goal. 1st King’s Royal Rifles—Nil

and 35 - 37 Noble Street LONDON, E.C.
English Tailors, Drapers and Outfitters.

ATHLETIC GOODS: A VARIED STOCK, INCLUDING Slazenger’s Doherty “E.G.M.” Demon. AND Ayre’s Central Strung Racquets.
TENNIS BALLS FRESH SUPPLY WEEKLY.
BOOTS & SHOES.
All the newest shapes in the best English makes:—
BUCKSKIN TENNIS BOOT AT £1 A SPECIALITY.
Owing to the increased business in this Department a new Showroom has been fitted up where better attention can be given to Customers.
CLOTHS: The largest Stock in Egypt of Cloths of the best British Manufacture : TROPICAL TWEEDS, FLANNELS, DRILLS, & c., & c
All garments cut by experienced English cutters. Fit and style guaranteed.
GENTS’ OUTFITTING: The newest Shades in Crepe de Chene Ties. Cellular, Oxford, Zephyr Shirts and Pyjamas in great variety.
Special Attention paid to Shirts Made to Measure.
HOSIERY AND UNDERCLOTHING IN THE BEST MAKES.
PANAMA, STRAW, & FELT HATS CORK & PITH HELMETS. CAPS.
HOUSEHOLD LINEN AT SPECIALLY CHEAP PRICES. TABLE CLOTHS, NAPKINS, SHEETS, AND PILLOW CASES. FLANNELETTES, VIYELLAS AND CEYLON FLANNELS.
SOAP, PERFUMERY, RUBBER SPONGES, BRUSHES, STUDS, MIRRORS (Hand & Shaving) FOUNTAIN PENS, &c., &c.
Davies Bryan & Co., Cairo & Alexandria.
